objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to develop an R package called 'MacBehaviour' that facilitates behavioural experimentation on large language models (LLMs) by providing a comprehensive set of functions for experiment design, stimuli presentation, model behaviour manipulation, and logging responses.
objective.evidence: We therefore developed an R package called 'MacBehaviour' that aims to interact with more than 60 language models in one package... and streamline the experimental process of LLMs behaviour experiments.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the lack of standard procedures for studying machine behaviour, which makes it difficult to compare results or build on previous research, limiting our collective grasp of LLM behaviour.
knowledge_gap.evidence: However, studying LLM behaviour presents two key challenges. The first is the lack of standard procedures for studying machine behaviour. This inconsistency makes it difficult to compare results or build on previous research, limiting our collective grasp of LLM behaviour.

answer: The development of an R package, 'MacBehaviour', that allows interaction with over 60 LLMs and streamlines the experimental process.
The package provides a user-friendly interface and abstracts away technical complexities, allowing researchers to focus on substantive aspects of their experiments.
It supports both cloud-based and self-hosted LLMs, offering a suite of functions for common experimental tasks.
evidence: We therefore developed an R package called 'MacBehaviour' that aims to interact with more than 60 language models in one package...
MacBehaviour abstracts away the technical complexities of interfacing with these models, allowing users to focus on the substantive aspects of their experiments.
The package offers a suite of functions for common experimental tasks, such as sending prompts, experiment design, and logging response and token probability.

performance_summary.summary: The package was validated through experiments showing consistent sound-gender association effects across different LLMs.
performance_summary.evidence: The results indicated a consistent trend across all models, with names ending with an open syllable more frequently associated with feminine genders.

baselines.name: ChatGPT and Vicuna
baselines.description: Used as baselines for replicating sound-gender association experiments.
baselines.evidence: Cai et al. (2023) replicated the experiment with ChatGPT and Vicuna and obtained a similar phonology-gender association in these LLMs.

limitations.name: Limited Generalizability
limitations.description: The experiments were conducted on a limited set of LLMs, which may not generalize to all available models.
limitations.evidence: We collected data from GPT-3.5 and also open-source models Llama-2 7B and Vicuna 1.5 13B (both deployed locally).
